fields.headline: Anthrax hoax chaos
fields.bodyText: Anthrax hoaxes have gripped America and the rest of the world, causing far more chaos than any of the genuinely poisoned letters. · In Portland, Maine, police chief Michael Chitwood blasted prosecutors for failing to press charges against a woman who sent white powder to the town's post office, causing it to close. The woman is mentally ill. · In Los Angeles a carpenter at the Queen Mary ship, now a tourist attraction, painted the words 'Danger. Do not open. Anthrax' on a waste bucket. He was charged and is now being held on $500,000 bail. · In Indianapolis four students face up to 18 months in prison and a $10,000 fine for writing 'This is anthrax' on a food container. In fact, it contained a cheeseburger and fries. · In Avondale, Mississippi, a 20-year-old man was arrested after spreading sugar in mail bins at a shipyard firm. · A FedEx deliveryman in Louisiana has been charged after putting a white powder in a parcel delivered to a woman client. He also drew a devil and wrote the letters 'USA' and 'Satan' on the parcel. · In Pearl City, Hawaii, a high school student was arrested after he brought white powder into school in an envelope. The building was evacuated and the pupil will be sent to another school for the rest of the year. · In Peru the country's biggest telecoms company evacuated its Lima headquarters after an envelope containing a white powder was sent from the US. · In France fast-track procedures have already seen four people convicted of anthrax hoaxes. More than 34 people in Paris alone were hospitalised during the week as precautionary measures. None tested positive. · In Ipswich, an official from Swedish football club Helsingborg had a letter with a white powder in pushed under his door. It was a prank played by two other guests but the hotel was decontaminated as a precaution. · In Spain a 22-year-old chemistry student was arrested for sending flour through the post. He was the second Spaniard to be arrested on hoax charges last week.
